node.title: Poem: [Thought at first that grief had brought him down.]
node.description: Ellen Bryant Voigt reminds us that there have been pandemics before. I go back to these poems to remember that if we can write about it, we can survive it.
node.content: ["In \u201cKyrie,\u201d these sonnets published way back in 1995, before I knew poetry or prison, Ellen Bryant Voigt reminds us that there have been pandemics before. There has been that absurd accumulation of suffering before. And I go back to these poems to remember that if we can write about it, we can survive it. This is what I tell my son when he asks how long the masks will last. Selected by Reginald Dwayne Betts", "By Ellen Bryant Voigt", "Thought at first that grief had brought him down.His wife dead, his own hand dug the graveunder a willow oak, in family ground \u2014he got home sick, was dead when morning came.By week\u2019s end, his cousin who worked in townwas seized at once by fever and by chill,left his office, walked back home at noon,death ripening in him like a boil.Soon it was a farmer in the field \u2014someone\u2019s brother, someone\u2019s father \u2014left the mule in its traces and went home.Then the mason, the miller at his wheel,from deep in the forest the hunter, the logger,and the sun still up everywhere in the kingdom."]
